author: pauld.9606
content:
This is an update on my rewrite of the witness spec.

I made major progress. Most notably, my rewrite is now much closer to <@!520564582196969472> 's spec, in hopes that it will be less controversial to merge.

There is some awkwardness. The Ethereum state tree includes restrictions like (i) leaf nodes are at a specific nibble-depth, (ii) extension nodes are not parents of extension or leaf nodes, (iii) the maximum nibble-depth is never exceeded, (iv) account nodes are not descendants of account nodes, and (v) nibbles must be handled somehow.

To capture all of these things, I had to add new syntax rules and new notation.

If there is negative feedback about too much syntax and notation, a solution may be to keep fewer syntax rules while dumping these extra restrictions into validation rules. So each syntax rule would have an associated semantics rule AND optional validation rules. I am sympathetic to "economy of thought", so I am willing to try this.

Judge for yourself whether the current draft has too much syntax and notation. It is at the same link as posted above, https://notes.ethereum.org/dfeV_C-pSI2h378AadR9DQ?view .

<@456226577798135808> <@!520564582196969472> <@!364458974906548225> and all interested parties, I will "hop-on" the witness voice channel on Monday, say at 6 PM Berlin time, noon New York time. I wish to briefly explain my witness spec rewrite, and ask for advice on whether and how to merge such a monster rewrite into the current witness spec doc.

author: Deleted User
content: the modification to go from hex to binary isn't going to be large. Spec for hexary allows us to compute witneses on the existing data. And we can do a lot of work on the witnesses regardless of whether they are hexary or binary. For example, we can spin up a new optional network for gossiping hex witnesses and play with partitioning to better relay
